play.title: Twelfth Night, or What You Will

scene.scenelocation: Illyria. A room in Duke Orsino’s palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter Orsino, Duke of Illyria, Curio, and other Lords; Musicians attending.

scene.line: How now, what news from her?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: So please my lord, I might not be admitted,
But from her handmaid do return this answer:
The element itself, till seven years’ heat,
Shall not behold her face at ample view;
But like a cloistress she will veiled walk,
And water once a day her chamber round
With eye-offending brine; all this to season
A brother’s dead love, which she would keep fresh
And lasting in her sad remembrance.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
How will she love when the rich golden shaft
Hath kill’d the flock of all affections else
That live in her; when liver, brain, and heart,
These sovereign thrones, are all supplied and fill’d
Her sweet perfections with one self king!
Away before me to sweet beds of flow’rs,
Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bow’rs.

stagedir.dir: Enter Viola, a Captain, and Sailors.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: What a plague means my niece to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure care’s an enemy to life.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier a’ nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Why, let her except before excepted.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Confine? I’ll confine myself no finer than I am. These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too; and they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: That quaffing and drinking will undo you. I heard my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Ay, he.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: He’s as tall a man as any’s in Illyria.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: What’s that to th’ purpose?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Ay, but he’ll have but a year in all these ducats. He’s a very fool and a prodigal.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Fie, that you’ll say so! He plays o’ th’ viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages word for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of nature.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: He hath indeed, almost natural; for besides that he’s a fool, he’s a great quarreller; and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarrelling, ’tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: By this hand, they are scoundrels and sub-stractors that say so of him. Who are they?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: They that add moreov’r, he’s drunk nightly in your company.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: With drinking healths to my niece. I’ll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat, and drink in Illyria. He’s a coward and a coystrill that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o’ th’ toe like a parish-top. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo! For here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: O knight, thou lack’st a cup of canary. When did I see thee so put down?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Never in your life I think, unless you see canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has; but I am a great eater of beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: No question.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: And I thought that, I’d forswear it. I’ll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: What is “pourquoi”? Do, or not do? I would I had bestow’d that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O had I but follow’d the arts!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Why, would that have mended my hair?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: But it becomes me well enough, does’t not?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Excellent, it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I hope to see a huswife take thee between her legs, and spin it off.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece will not be seen, or if she be, it’s four to one she’ll none of me. The Count himself here hard by woos her.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: She’ll none o’ th’ Count. She’ll not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I have heard her swear’t. Tut, there’s life in’t, man.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: I’ll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o’ th’ strangest mind i’ th’ world; I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters, and yet I will not compare with an old man.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Faith, I can cut a caper.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: And I can cut the mutton to’t.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before ’em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture? Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard, and come home in a coranto? My very walk should be a jig.

I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in? I did think by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was form’d under the star of a galliard.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Ay, ’tis strong; and it does indifferent well in a dun-color’d stock. Shall we set about some revels?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Taurus? That’s sides and heart.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see thee caper. Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!

scene.scenelocation: A room in Duke Orsino’s palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter Valentine, and Viola in man’s attire.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I thank you. Here comes the Count.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Who saw Cesario, ho?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: On your attendance, my lord, here.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Stand you awhile aloof. Cesario,
Thou know’st no less but all. I have unclasp’d
To thee the book even of my secret soul.
Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her,
Be not denied access, stand at her doors,
And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow
Till thou have audience.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Sure, my noble lord,
If she be so abandon’d to her sorrow
As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds,
Rather than make unprofited return.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: O then, unfold the passion of my love,
Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith;
It shall become thee well to act my woes:
She will attend it better in thy youth
Than in a nuntio’s of more grave aspect.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I think not so, my lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Dear lad, believe it;
For they shall yet belie thy happy years,
That say thou art a man. Diana’s lip
Is not more smooth and rubious; thy small pipe
Is as the maiden’s organ, shrill and sound,
And all is semblative a woman’s part.
I know thy constellation is right apt
For this affair. Some four or five attend him—
All, if you will; for I myself am best
When least in company. Prosper well in this,
And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,
To call his fortunes thine.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I’ll do my best
To woo your lady.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter, in way of thy excuse. My lady will hang thee for thy absence.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Let her hang me! He that is well hang’d in this world needs to fear no colors.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Make that good.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: He shall see none to fear.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that saying was born, of “I fear no colors.”

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Where, good Mistress Mary?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: In the wars, and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, God give them wisdom that have it; and those that are fools, let them use their talents.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Yet you will be hang’d for being so long absent, or to be turn’d away—is not that as good as a hanging to you?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage; and for turning away, let summer bear it out.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: You are resolute then?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Not so, neither, but I am resolv’d on two points—

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: That if one break, the other will hold; or if both break, your gaskins fall.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way, if Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve’s flesh as any in Illyria.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Peace, you rogue, no more o’ that. Here comes my lady. Make your excuse wisely, you were best.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Wit, and’t be thy will, put me into good fooling! Those wits that think they have thee do very oft prove fools; and I that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus? “Better a witty fool than a foolish wit.”—God bless thee, lady!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Take the fool away.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Go to, y’ are a dry fool; I’ll no more of you. Besides, you grow dishonest.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend; for give the dry fool drink, then is the fool not dry; bid the dishonest man mend himself: if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Any thing that’s mended is but patch’d; virtue that transgresses is but patch’d with sin, and sin that amends is but patch’d with virtue. If that this simple syllogism will serve, so; if it will not, what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty’s a flower. The lady bade take away the fool, therefore I say again, take her away.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Sir, I bade them take away you.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, “Cucullus non facit monachum”: that’s as much to say as I wear not motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Can you do it?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Dexteriously, good madonna.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Make your proof.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I must catechize you for it, madonna. Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide your proof.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Good madonna, why mourn’st thou?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Good fool, for my brother’s death.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul, being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? Doth he not mend?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him. Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for twopence that you are no fool.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: How say you to that, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal. I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that has no more brain than a stone. Look you now, he’s out of his guard already. Unless you laugh and minister occasion to him, he is gagg’d. I protest I take these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools’ zanies.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: O, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distemper’d appetite. To be generous, guiltless, and of free disposition, is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets. There is no slander in an allow’d fool, though he do nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Now Mercury indue thee with leasing, for thou speak’st well of fools!
Go you, Malvolio; if it be a suit from the Count, I am sick, or not at home—what you will, to dismiss it.
One of thy kin has a most weak pia mater.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: By mine honor, half drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: A gentleman.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: A gentleman? What gentleman?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: ’Tis a gentleman here—a plague o’ these pickle-herring! How now, sot?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Good Sir Toby!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Lechery! I defy lechery. There’s one at the gate.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay, marry, what is he?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Let him be the devil and he will, I care not; give me faith say I. Well, it’s all one.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: The honorable lady of the house, which is she?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Speak to me, I shall answer for her. Your will?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty—I pray you tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her. I would be loath to cast away my speech; for besides that it is excellently well penn’d, I have taken great pains to con it. Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn; I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Whence came you, sir?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part. Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Are you a comedian?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: No, my profound heart; and yet (by the very fangs of malice I swear) I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself; for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve. But this is from my commission; I will on with my speech in your praise, and then show you the heart of my message.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Come to what is important in’t. I forgive you the praise.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and ’tis poetical.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: It is the more like to be feign’d, I pray you keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates, and allow’d your approach rather to wonder at you than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone. If you have reason, be brief. ’Tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady. Tell me your mind—I am a messenger.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Sure you have some hideous matter to deliver, when the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage; I hold the olive in my hand; my words are as full of peace as matter.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Yet you began rudely. What are you? What would you?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: The rudeness that hath appear’d in me have I learn’d from my entertainment. What I am, and what I would, are as secret as maidenhead: to your ears, divinity; to any other’s, profanation.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Give us the place alone, we will hear this divinity.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Here, madam, at your service.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Run after that same peevish messenger,
The County’s man. He left this ring behind him,
Would I or not. Tell him I’ll none of it.
Desire him not to flatter with his lord,
Nor hold him up with hopes: I am not for him.
If that the youth will come this way tomorrow,
I’ll give him reasons for’t. Hie thee, Malvolio.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
I have many enemies in Orsino’s court,
Else would I very shortly see thee there.
But come what may, I do adore thee so
That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Were you not ev’n now with the Countess Olivia?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Even now, sir; on a moderate pace I have since arriv’d but hither.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have sav’d me my pains, to have taken it away yourself. She adds moreover, that you should put your lord into a desperate assurance she will none of him. And one thing more, that you be never so hardy to come again in his affairs, unless it be to report your lord’s taking of this. Receive it so.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: She took the ring of me, I’ll none of it.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her; and her will is, it should be so return’d. If it be worth stooping for, there it lies, in your eye; if not, be it his that finds it.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Toby and Sir Andrew.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Here comes the fool, i’ faith.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: How now, my hearts? Did you never see the picture of “we three”?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Welcome, ass. Now let’s have a catch.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night, when thou spok’st of Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. ’Twas very good, i’ faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy leman; hadst it?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I did impeticos thy gratillity; for Malvolio’s nose is no whipstock. My lady has a white hand, and the Mermidons are no bottle-ale houses.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling, when all is done. Now a song.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come on, there is sixpence for you. Let’s have a song.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: There’s a testril of me too. If one knight give a—

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: A love-song, a love-song.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Ay, ay. I care not for good life.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What is love? ’Tis not hereafter;
Present mirth hath present laughter;
What’s to come is still unsure.
In delay there lies no plenty,
Then come kiss me sweet and twenty;
Youth’s a stuff will not endure.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: A contagious breath.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Very sweet and contagious, i’ faith.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? Shall we rouse the night-owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: And you love me, let’s do’t. I am dog at a catch.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: By’r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Most certain. Let our catch be “Thou knave.”

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: “Hold thy peace, thou knave,” knight? I shall be constrain’d in’t to call thee knave, knight.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: ’Tis not the first time I have constrain’d one to call me knave. Begin, fool. It begins, “Hold thy peace.”

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Good, i’ faith. Come, begin.

scene.line: Am not I consanguineous? Am I not of her blood? Tilly-vally! Lady!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: For the love o’ God, peace!

scene.line: “Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.”

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, good Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: “But I will never die.”

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Sir Toby, there you lie.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: This is much credit to you.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: “What and if you do?”

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: “O no, no, no, no, you dare not.”

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Art any more than a steward? Dost thou think because thou art virtuous there shall be no more cakes and ale?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i’ th’ mouth too.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Th’ art i’ th’ right. Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs. A stope of wine, Maria!

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Mistress Mary, if you priz’d my lady’s favor at any thing more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule. She shall know of it, by this hand.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Good night, Penthesilea.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Before me, she’s a good wench.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: She’s a beagle true-bred, and one that adores me. What o’ that?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: I was ador’d once too.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Let’s to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for more money.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Send for money, knight; if thou hast her not i’ th’ end, call me cut.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, come, I’ll go burn some sack, ’tis too late to go to bed now. Come, knight, come, knight.

scene.scenelocation: A room in Duke Orsino’s palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and others.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: O fellow, come, the song we had last night.
Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain.
The spinsters and the knitters in the sun,
And the free maids that weave their thread with bones,
Do use to chaunt it. It is silly sooth,
And dallies with the innocence of love,
Like the old age.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Are you ready, sir?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Ay, prithee sing.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Come away, come away, death,
And in sad cypress let me be laid.
Fly away, fly away, breath,
I am slain by a fair cruel maid.
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
O, prepare it!
My part of death, no one so true
Did share it.
Not a flower, not a flower sweet
On my black coffin let there be strown.
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown.
A thousand thousand sighs to save,
Lay me, O, where
Sad true lover never find my grave,
To weep there.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: There’s for thy pains.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No pains, sir, I take pleasure in singing, sir.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: I’ll pay thy pleasure then.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Give me now leave to leave thee.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Now the melancholy god protect thee, and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffata, for thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be every thing and their intent every where, for that’s it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll come. If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boil’d to death with melancholy.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: I would exult, man. You know he brought me out o’ favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: To anger him we’ll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue, shall we not, Sir Andrew?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: And we do not, it is pity of our lives.

line.recite: “To the unknown belov’d, this, and my good wishes”:—

scene.line: Her very phrases! By your leave, wax. Soft! And the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal. ’Tis my lady. To whom should this be?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: This wins him, liver and all.

line.recite: But silence, like a Lucrece knife,
With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore;

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: A fustian riddle!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Excellent wench, say I.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.” Nay, but first let me see, let me see, let me see.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: What dish a’ poison has she dress’d him!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: And with what wing the staniel checks at it!

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “I may command where I adore.” Why, she may command me: I serve her, she is my lady. Why, this is evident to any formal capacity, there is no obstruction in this. And the end—what should that alphabetical position portend? If I could make that resemble something in me! Softly! M.O.A.I.—

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: O ay, make up that. He is now at a cold scent.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Sowter will cry upon’t for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: M—Malvolio; M—why, that begins my name.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Did not I say he would work it out? The cur is excellent at faults.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: M—but then there is no consonancy in the sequel that suffers under probation: A should follow, but O does.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: And O shall end, I hope.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Ay, or I’ll cudgel him, and make him cry O!

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: And then I comes behind.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Ay, and you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: M.O.A.I. This simulation is not as the former; and yet, to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name. Soft, here follows prose.

line.recite: “If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon ’em. Thy Fates open their hands, let thy blood and spirit embrace them, and to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants; let thy tongue tang arguments of state; put thyself into the trick of singularity. She thus advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy yellow stockings, and wish’d to see thee ever cross-garter’d: I say, remember. Go to, thou art made if thou desir’st to be so; if not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune’s fingers. Farewell. She that would alter services with thee,

speech.line: Daylight and champian discovers not more. This is open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point-devise the very man. I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me; for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me. She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-garter’d, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction drives me to these habits of her liking. I thank my stars, I am happy. I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-garter’d, even with the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be prais’d! Here is yet a postscript.

line.recite: “Thou canst not choose but know who I am. If thou entertain’st my love, let it appear in thy smiling; thy smiles become thee well. Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.”

speech.line: Jove, I thank thee. I will smile, I will do every thing that thou wilt have me.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Nor I neither.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Wilt thou set thy foot o’ my neck?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Or o’ mine either?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bond-slave?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: I’ faith, or I either?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream, that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Like aqua-vitae with a midwife.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady. He will come to her in yellow stockings, and ’tis a color she abhors, and cross-garter’d, a fashion she detests; and he will smile upon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow me.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: I’ll make one too.

stagedir.dir: Enter Viola, and Clown with a tabor.

scene.line: though I would not have it grow on my chin. Is thy lady within?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Yes, being kept together, and put to use.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring a Cressida to this Troilus.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I understand you, sir. ’Tis well begg’d.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir—begging but a beggar: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within, sir. I will conster to them whence you come; who you are, and what you would, are out of my welkin—I might say “element,” but the word is overworn.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool,
And to do that well craves a kind of wit.
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,
The quality of persons, and the time;
And like the haggard, check at every feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practice
As full of labor as a wise man’s art;
For folly that he wisely shows is fit,
But wise men, folly-fall’n, quite taint their wit.

scene.line: Most excellent accomplish’d lady, the heavens rain odors on you!

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: That youth’s a rare courtier—“rain odors,” well.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: “Odors,” “pregnant,” and “vouchsafed”; I’ll get ’em all three all ready.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Olivia and Viola.

speech.line: The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you,
And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,
Your wife is like to reap a proper man.
There lies your way, due west.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Then westward-ho!
Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship!
You’ll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Stay!
I prithee tell me what thou think’st of me.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: That you do think you are not what you are.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: If I think so, I think the same of you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I would you were as I would have you be.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murd’rous guilt shows not itself more soon
Than love that would seem hid: love’s night is noon.—
Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
By maidhood, honor, truth, and every thing,
I love thee so, that maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause;
But rather reason thus with reason fetter:
Love sought is good, but given unsought is better.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: By innocence I swear, and by my youth,
I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,
And that no woman has, nor never none
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam, never more
Will I my master’s tears to you deplore.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Yet come again; for thou perhaps mayst move
That heart which now abhors, to like his love.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: We shall have a rare letter from him; but you’ll not deliver’t?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Never trust me then; and by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wain-ropes cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were open’d and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I’ll eat the rest of th’ anatomy.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I have sent after him; he says he’ll come.
How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begg’d or borrow’d.
I speak too loud.—
Where’s Malvolio? He is sad and civil,
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
Where is Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: He’s coming, madam, but in very strange manner. He is sure possess’d, madam.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Why, what’s the matter? Does he rave?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you, if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Go call him hither.

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is return’d. I could hardly entreat him back. He attends your ladyship’s pleasure.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I’ll come to him.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: O ho, do you come near me now? No worse man than Sir Toby to look to me! This concurs directly with the letter: she sends him on purpose, that I may appear stubborn to him; for she incites me to that in the letter. “Cast thy humble slough,” says she; “be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants; let thy tongue tang with arguments of state; put thyself into the trick of singularity”; and consequently sets down the manner how: as a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have lim’d her, but it is Jove’s doing, and Jove make me thankful! And when she went away now, “Let this fellow be look’d to”; “fellow”! Not “Malvolio,” nor after my degree, but “fellow.” Why, every thing adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance—What can be said? Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thank’d.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: If this were play’d upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air, and taint.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: The house will be the quieter.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound. My niece is already in the belief that he’s mad. We may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance, till our very pastime, tir’d out of breath, prompt us to have mercy on him; at which time we will bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see.

line.recite: “Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Good, and valiant.

line.recite: “Thou com’st to the Lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly. But thou liest in thy throat, that is not the matter I challenge thee for.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.

line.recite: “Thou kill’st me like a rogue and a villain.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Still you keep o’ th’ windy side of the law; good.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Now will not I deliver his letter; for the behavior of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity and breeding; his employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less. Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth; he will find it comes from a clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity. This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I have said too much unto a heart of stone,
And laid mine honor too unchary on’t.
There’s something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is
That it but mocks reproof.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: With the same havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master’s griefs.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Here, wear this jewel for me, ’tis my picture.
Refuse it not, it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again tomorrow.
What shall you ask of me that I’ll deny,
That honor, sav’d, may upon asking give?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Nothing but this—your true love for my master.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: How with mine honor may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I will acquit you.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well.
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Gentleman, God save thee!

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: And you, sir.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: That defense thou hast, betake thee to’t. Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not; but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard-end. Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: You mistake, sir, I am sure; no man hath any quarrel to me. My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you; therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard; for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath can furnish man withal.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, what is he?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: He is knight, dubb’d with unhatch’d rapier, and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl. Souls and bodies hath he divorc’d three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable, that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word; give’t or take’t.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I will return again into the house, and desire some conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor. Belike this is a man of that quirk.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury; therefore get you on, and give him his desire. Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him; therefore on, or strip your sword stark naked; for meddle you must, that’s certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is. It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Why, man, he’s a very devil, I have not seen such a firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all; and he gives me the stuck in with such a mortal motion that it is inevitable; and on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hits the ground they step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Pox on’t, I’ll not meddle with him.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Ay, but he will not now be pacified. Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Plague on’t, and I thought he had been valiant, and so cunning in fence, I’d have seen him damn’d ere I’d have challeng’d him. Let him let the matter slip, and I’ll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I’ll make the motion. Stand here, make a good show on’t; this shall end without the perdition of souls.

There’s no remedy, sir, he will fight with you for ’s oath sake. Marry, he hath better bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking of; therefore draw, for the supportance of his vow. He protests he will not hurt you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Give ground if you see him furious.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy, the gentleman will for his honor’s sake have one bout with you. He cannot by the duello avoid it; but he has promis’d me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on, to’t.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Pray God he keep his oath!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offense, I take the fault on me;
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: You, sir? Why, what are you?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: O good Sir Toby, hold! Here come the officers.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: This comes with seeking you;
But there’s no remedy, I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amaz’d,
But be of comfort.

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Come, sir, away.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I must entreat of you some of that money.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have show’d me here,
And part being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I’ll lend you something. My having is not much;
I’ll make division of my present with you.
Hold, there’s half my coffer.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Will you deny me now?
Is’t possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I know of none,
Nor know I you by voice or any feature.
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: O heavens themselves!

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Come, sir, I pray you go.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatch’d one half out of the jaws of death,
Reliev’d him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: What’s that to us? The time goes by; away!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: But O, how vild an idol proves this god!
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there’s no blemish but the mind;
None can be call’d deform’d but the unkind.
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o’erflourish’d by the devil.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: The man grows mad, away with him! Come, come, sir.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Lead me on.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare. His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity, and denying him; and for his cowardship, ask Fabian.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: ’Slid, I’ll after him again, and beat him.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: And I do not—

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow,
Let me be clear of thee.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well held out, i’ faith! No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither: nothing that is so is so.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I prithee vent thy folly somewhere else,
Thou know’st not me.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Vent my folly! He has heard that word of some great man, and now applies it to a fool. Vent my folly! I am afraid this great lubber the world will prove a cockney. I prithee now ungird thy strangeness, and tell me what I shall vent to my lady. Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me.
There’s money for thee. If you tarry longer,
I shall give worse payment.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years’ purchase.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Why, there’s for thee, and there, and there.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Hold, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger o’er the house.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come on, sir, hold!

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Nay, let him alone. I’ll go another way to work with him; I’ll have an action of battery against him, if there be any law in Illyria. Though I strook him first, yet it’s no matter for that.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Let go thy hand.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young soldier, put up your iron; you are well flesh’d. Come on.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I will be free from thee.

stagedir.dir: Breaks away and draws his sword.

speech.line: I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botch’d up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this. Thou shalt not choose but go;
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me,
He started one poor heart of mine, in thee.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: What relish is in this? How runs the stream?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream.
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep;
If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Nay, come, I prithee. Would thou’dst be rul’d by me!

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: O, say so, and so be!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, I’ll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in’t, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good studient; but to be said an honest man and a good house-keeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I am gone, sir,
And anon, sir,
I’ll be with you again;
In a trice,
Like to the old Vice,
Your need to sustain;
Who with dagger of lath,
In his rage and his wrath,
Cries, ah, ha! To the devil;
Like a mad lad,
Pare thy nails, dad.
Adieu, goodman devil.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: This is the air, that is the glorious sun,
This pearl she gave me, I do feel’t and see’t,
And though ’tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet ’tis not madness. Where’s Antonio then?
I could not find him at the Elephant,
Yet there he was, and there I found this credit,
That he did range the town to seek me out.
His counsel now might do me golden service,
For though my soul disputes well with my sense,
That this may be some error, but no madness,
Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am ready to distrust mine eyes,
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad,
Or else the lady’s mad; yet if ’twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take and give back affairs, and their dispatch,
With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing
As I perceive she does. There’s something in’t
That is deceivable. But here the lady comes.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Now as thou lov’st me, let me see his letter.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Any thing.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Do not desire to see this letter.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: This is to give a dog and in recompense desire my dog again.

stagedir.dir: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and Lords.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Here comes the Countess, now heaven walks on earth.
But for thee, fellow—fellow, thy words are madness.
Three months this youth hath tended upon me,
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What would my lord, but that he may not have,
Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Madam—

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Gracious Olivia—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord—

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: My lord would speak, my duty hushes me.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear
As howling after music.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Still so cruel?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Still so constant, lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: What, to perverseness? You uncivil lady,
To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars
My soul the faithfull’st off’rings have breath’d out
That e’er devotion tender’d! What shall I do?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Why should I not (had I the heart to do it),
Like to th’ Egyptian thief at point of death,
Kill what I love? (a savage jealousy
That sometime savors nobly), but hear me this:
Since you to non-regardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screws me from my true place in your favor,
Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still.
But this your minion, whom I know you love,
And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,
Him will I tear out of that cruel eye,
Where he sits crowned in his master’s spite.
Come, boy, with me, my thoughts are ripe in mischief.
I’ll sacrifice the lamb that I do love,
To spite a raven’s heart within a dove.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: And I most jocund, apt, and willingly,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Where goes Cesario?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: After him I love
More than I love these eyes, more than my life,
More by all mores than e’er I shall love wife.
If I do feign, you witnesses above
Punish my life for tainting of my love!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay me, detested! How am I beguil’d!

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Who does beguile you? Who does do you wrong?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Hast thou forgot thyself? Is it so long?
Call forth the holy father.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Come, away!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Husband?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay, husband. Can he that deny?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Her husband, sirrah?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: No, my lord, not I.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear
That makes thee strangle thy propriety.
Fear not, Cesario, take thy fortunes up,
Be that thou know’st thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear’st.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: H’as broke my head across, and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too. For the love of God, your help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: The Count’s gentleman, one Cesario. We took him for a coward, but he’s the very devil incardinate.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: My gentleman, Cesario?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: ’Od’s lifelings, here he is! You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do’t by Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you.
I drew your sword upon me without cause,
But I bespake you fair, and hurt you not.
So comes it, lady, you have been mistook;
But Nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid,
Nor are you therein, by my life, deceiv’d,
You are betroth’d both to a maid and man.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Be not amaz’d, right noble is his blood.
If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,
I shall have share in this most happy wrack.
A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banish’d his.
How does he, sirrah?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at the stave’s end as well as a man in his case may do. H’as here writ a letter to you; I should have given’t you today morning. But as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are deliver’d.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Open’t and read it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman.
Read it you, sirrah.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: My lord, so please you, these things further thought on,
To think me as well a sister as a wife,
One day shall crown th’ alliance on’t, so please you,
Here at my house and at my proper cost.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Madam, I am most apt t’ embrace your offer.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Is this the madman?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay, my lord, this same.
How now, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Madam, you have done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Have I, Malvolio? No.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Lady, you have. Pray you peruse that letter.
You must not now deny it is your hand;
Write from it if you can, in hand or phrase,
Or say ’tis not your seal, not your invention.
You can say none of this. Well, grant it then,
And tell me, in the modesty of honor,
Why you have given me such clear lights of favor,
Bade me come smiling and cross-garter’d to you,
To put on yellow stockings, and to frown
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And acting this in an obedient hope,
Why have you suffer’d me to be imprison’d,
Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
And made the most notorious geck and gull
That e’er invention play’d on? Tell me why!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,
Though I confess much like the character;
But out of question ’tis Maria’s hand.
And now I do bethink me, it was she
First told me thou wast mad. Then cam’st in smiling,
And in such forms which here were presuppos’d
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee be content.
This practice hath most shrewdly pass’d upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge
Of thine own cause.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Good madam, hear me speak,
And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come
Taint the condition of this present hour,
Which I have wond’red at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confess, myself and Toby
Set this device against Malvolio here,
Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts
We had conceiv’d against him. Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby’s great importance,
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was follow’d
May rather pluck on laughter than revenge,
If that the injuries be justly weigh’d
That have on both sides pass’d.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them.” I was one, sir, in this enterlude—one Sir Topas, sir, but that’s all one. “By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.” But do you remember? “Madam, why laugh you at such a barren rascal? And you smile not, he’s gagg’d.” And thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: I’ll be reveng’d on the whole pack of you.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: When that I was and a little tiny boy,
With hey ho, the wind and the rain,
A foolish thing was but a toy,
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to man’s estate,
With hey ho, etc.
’Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,
For the rain, etc.
But when I came, alas, to wive,
With hey ho, etc.
By swaggering could I never thrive,
For the rain, etc.
But when I came unto my beds,
With hey ho, etc.
With toss-pots still had drunken heads,
For the rain, etc.
A great while ago the world begun,
With hey ho, etc.
But that’s all one, our play is done,
And we’ll strive to please you every day.

sourcedetails.notice: This copyright notice may not be removed under any circumstance.
